thread.title: The Lenin and Stalin impersonators outside the Kremlin who've embraced capitalism: Lookalikes charge tourists £10 a go to have photographs taken with them
thread.title_full: The Lenin and Stalin impersonators outside the Kremlin who've embraced capitalism: Lookalikes charge tourists £10 a go to have photographs taken with them | Daily Mail Online

author: John Hutchinson for MailOnline
title: The Lenin and Stalin impersonators outside the Kremlin who've embraced capitalism: Lookalikes charge tourists £10 a go to have photographs taken with them
text:
View
comments
Lenin and Stalin weren't known for chasing profits - but the lookalikes of the communist leaders that swarm around the Kremlin don't seem to care.
Often dressed in military uniforms, and normally with the communist flag ready to be unfurled, a number of Russian impersonators patrol the square offering tourists the chance to have their photograph taken with them.
But they have to fish out as much as £10 (1,000 rubles) a go for a photo with one of the political heavyweights. And it pays to do some research on who is the best lookalike.
Men dressed as Russian communists Lenin (left) and Stalin (right) charge tourists in the Red Square up to £10 for a photo
If you want to get a memorable photo from Red Square, it's probably best to ask 'Stalin' to lay down the McDonald's fries
Would they be turning in their graves? It's unlikely Stalin (left) and Lenin (right) would be happy with some of their imposters
For starters, one Stalin imposter has been pictured stuffing his face with McDonald's chips in the shadow of the Kremlin.
There's also a drunk 'Lenin', who struggles to focus on the camera.
 Not a beach or infinity pool in sight: The photographer who... Truly novel tourist attractions! Inside the world's most... Turkish delight! Why visitors come back again and again to... Passenger who was arrested and led off plane in handcuffs by... Sergei Solovyov, a 57-year-old Lenin impersonator told the Wall Street Journal : 'It's hard work to be on your feet all day, he said.
'It's also morally hard. People shout: 'Burn in hell! What have you done with Russia?'
Lenin served as head of government of the Russian Soviet Federative Socialist Republic from 1917, and of the Soviet Union from 1922 until his death in 1924, Stalin took over and led the Soviet Union until 1953
There have also been reports of squabbles breaking out among the impersonators. One Stalin-lookalike followed a 'Lenin' into an alleyway and 'jabbed him with an umbrella' in a row over the dividing up of cash.
Recognising the opportunity for income, the impersonating started in the 1990s, and it's believed six 'Stalins' and eight 'Lenins' now work the crowds.
Solovyov added: '"White Lenin" has a pale face; "Wooden Lenin" doesn't say much; "Gay Lenin" stands with an impersonator of the poet Alexander Pushkin; "Drunk Lenin" likes a tipple.'
Lenin led the Bolshevik Revolution that established seven decades of Soviet rule.
Stalin succeeded him, purging millions of citizens but leading the USSR to victory in the Second World War.
The Russian men have a chat to discuss how their daily takings are shaping up in Red Square
VLADIMIR LENIN Vladmir Lenin was behind the Bolshevik take-over of power in Russia in 1917. He was also the architect and first head of the USSR.
Born in Simbirsk, he was expelled from university for his radical policies while studying law. This prompted him to move to St Petersburg, where he became a revolutionary.
He was arrested and exiled to Siberia. He later spent most of his time in western Europe, where he became the leader of the 'Bolshevik' faction of the Russian Social Democratic Worker's Party.
In 1917, Lenin returned to Russia where he led what was to be known as the October Revolution. Around three years of civil war followed in which millions died.
In 1918, Lenin survived an assassination attempt, but was severely wounded. In 1922 he suffered a stroke from which he never fully recovered.
JOSEPH STALIN Stalin was one of the seven members of the first Politburo, founded in 1917 in order to manage the Bolshevik Revolution, alongside Lenin, Zinoviev, Kamenev, Trotsky, Sokolnikov and Bubnov.
Among the Bolshevik revolutionaries who took part in the Russian Revolution of 1917, Stalin was appointed General Secretary of the party's Central Committee in 1922.
He subsequently managed to consolidate power following the 1924 death of Lenin through suppressing his criticisms and expanding the functions of his role, all the while eliminating any opposition.
He remained general secretary until the post was abolished in 1952, concurrently serving as the Premier of the Soviet Union from 1941 onward.
Stalin remains a controversial figure today, with many regarding him as a tyrant.
Read more: In Moscow, Lenin and Stalin Look-Alikes Jostle for Tourists’ Cash - WSJ
